Package com.atakmap.map

Class AtakMapView

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.view.View
      • android.view.ViewGroup
        • com.atakmap.map.AtakMapView
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.graphics.drawable.Drawable.Callback, android.view.accessibility.AccessibilityEventSource, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, android.view.ViewManager, android.view.ViewParent
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MapView
    public class AtakMapView
extends android.view.ViewGroup

    Coordinate Systems

    The map is the result of the composition of several different coordinate systems. At a high level, these coordinate systems allow for conversion between Earth coordinates (geodetic latitude and longitude) and pixel coordinates of the {@see android.graphics.View View}. The forward coordinate system stack transforms latitude, longitude into pixel x, y; the inverse coordinate stack transform pixel x, y into latitude, longitude. The map provides corresponding methods, forward(GeoPoint) and inverse(PointF), respectively.

    For users implementing their own Open GL rendering code, the GLMapView class provides a set of its own forward and inverse methods that will transform points between OpenGL scene coordinates and latitude, longitude.

    Map scale is based on the physical size of the pixels on the device, with a scale of 1.0d being achieved when a distance of one inch measured on the map is equal to one inch on the physical screen. The scale is nominal and does not take into account local scale factors based on the projection. Map resolution is the measure of map distance, in meters, per pixel on the screen. For example, a resolution of 10 means that a line 5 pixels long nominally equates to 50 meters. As with scale, this value is nominal and should not be used for mensuration purposes.

    Map Life-Cycle

    Users should couple several of the Activity callbacks with method calls in the AtakMapView.

    • Activity.onPause()

      When the Activity is paused, pause() should be invoked.

    • Activity.onResume()

      When the Activity is resumed, pause() should be invoked.

    • Activity.onDestroy()

      When the Activity is paused, destroy() should be invoked.

    The destroy() method should only be invoked when the map is no longer needed. This method will release all associated resources and any subsequent attempt to use the map may result in undefined and undesirable behavior.

    Map Layers

    The map supports programmatic addition, removal and ordering of map layers. The layers framework is completely pluggable, meaning that users may seamlessly integrate their own custom layers at compile time or runtime. A description pluggable framework can be found in the documentation for the interface, Layer.

      • updateView

        public void updateView​(double latitude,
                       double longitude,
                       double scale,
                       double rotation,
                       double tilt,
                       boolean animate)
        Call to update the view provided a latitude, longitude, scale, rotation, tilt and a flag for animation.
        Parameters:
        latitude - the latitude in decimal degrees
        longitude - the longitude in decimal degrees
        scale - a number between getMinMapScale() and getMaxMapScale()
        tilt - a number between 0 (nadir) and 89
        animate - if the resulting update should animate (fly) to the new location

      • getDisplayDpi

        public double getDisplayDpi()

      • pause

        public void pause()
        Pauses the map rendering engine. It is recommended that this method is invoked when the activity containing the map is paused.

      • resume

        public void resume()
        Resumes the map rendering engine. This method should always be invoked in response to a previous invocation of pause().

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Destroys the map and releases any allocated resources. This method should only be invoked when the map is no longer going to be used; subsequent invocation of any method will result in undefined behavior, including exceptions being thrown.

      • getGLSurface

        public GLMapSurface getGLSurface()
        Returns the GLMapSurface that is being used to render the map.

        This method should not be invoked by most users. All rendering objects will have access to the returned GLMapSurface via the GLMapView instance provided to the renderable's draw method.

        Returns:
        the GLMapSurface that is being used to render the map.

        public GeoPointMetaData inverse​(float x,
                                float y)
        Computes the corresponding geodetic coordinate for the specified screen coordinate. This is a convienence method for calling inverse(float, float, InverseMode.Raycast)
        Parameters:

        y - A screen coordinate, y pixel

      • getInverseTransform

        public Projection getInverseTransform​(Matrix xform,
                                      GeoPoint focusGeo,
                                      float focusX,
                                      float focusY,
                                      double rotation,
                                      double scale)

        This method should generally not be invoked, use inverse(PointF) instead!

        Obtains the inverse transform to transform a point on the screen into a geodetic coordinate, assuming the following parameters about the display, using the current Projection.

        Parameters:
        xform - Returns the projection
        focusGeo - The focus of the screen, as a geodetic coordinate
        focusX - The focus of the screen, x-pixel coordinate
        focusY - The focus of the screen, y-pixel coordinate
        rotation - The rotation of the screen in degrees
        scale - The scale of the map displayed on the screen
        Returns:
        The current projection for which the inverse transform is valid

      • getInverseTransform

        public void getInverseTransform​(Projection proj,
                                Matrix xform,
                                GeoPoint focusGeo,
                                float focusX,
                                float focusY,
                                double rotation,
                                double tilt,
                                double mapScale)

        This method should generally not be invoked, use inverse(PointF) instead!

        Obtains the inverse transform to transform a point on the screen into a geodetic coordinate, assuming the following parameters about the display, using the current Projection.

        Parameters:
        proj - The projection to be used
        xform - Returns the projection to transform screen coordinates into the projected coordinate space
        focusGeo - The focus of the screen, as a geodetic coordinate
        focusX - The focus of the screen, x-pixel coordinate
        focusY - The focus of the screen, y-pixel coordinate
        rotation - The rotation of the screen in degrees
        mapScale - The scale of the map displayed on the screen
